pullRequest.body:
This PR defines the covolume of a `Zlattice` as the (finite) volume of any of its fundamental domain and proves some results about it, mainly: it's nonzero, it does not depend of the choice of the fundamental domain and it is equal to the absolute value of the determinant of any basis of the lattice. 

This PR also creates a directory `Zlattice` (with the original file becoming `Zlattice/Basic.lean`) and a new file `Zlattice/Covolume.lean`.



---

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#11323~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#11321~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

> This is surely my fault as I don't know the measure theory part of the library, but can you clarify the role of `Œº`?

I am not sure what you mean. The covolume is defined as the volume of any fundamental domain so it is necessary to provide a measure since the hypothesis we have on the ambient space `E` does not ensure that there is a canonical measure on it. It is true that, in most practical cases, `E` will be a `MeasureSpace` so we just want to use the volume of `E`. The tactic `volume_tac` does that automatically is `Œº` is not provided.

> > This is surely my fault as I don't know the measure theory part of the library, but can you clarify the role of `Œº`?
> 
> I am not sure what you mean. The covolume is defined as the volume of any fundamental domain so it is necessary to provide a measure since the hypothesis we have on the ambient space `E` does not ensure that there is a canonical measure on it. It is true that, in most practical cases, `E` will be a `MeasureSpace` so we just want to use the volume of `E`. The tactic `volume_tac` does that automatically is `Œº` is not provided.

So in practice if I have a lattice in, say, `‚ÑÇ` and I want to use the standard Lebesgue measure I have to write it explicitly?

> > > This is surely my fault as I don't know the measure theory part of the library, but can you clarify the role of `Œº`?
> > 
> > 
> > I am not sure what you mean. The covolume is defined as the volume of any fundamental domain so it is necessary to provide a measure since the hypothesis we have on the ambient space `E` does not ensure that there is a canonical measure on it. It is true that, in most practical cases, `E` will be a `MeasureSpace` so we just want to use the volume of `E`. The tactic `volume_tac` does that automatically is `Œº` is not provided.
> 
> So in practice if I have a lattice in, say, `‚ÑÇ` and I want to use the standard Lebesgue measure I have to write it explicitly?

Well, we could write `covolume L volume` (in fact, `MeasureTheory.MeasureSpace.volume`) or just `covolume L` (as it is written in `covolume_eq_det`) since Lean can infer automatically what the measure is since it is a `MeasureSpace`. It is only if you want to use an "unusual" measure (or the space `E` has no "canonical" measure) that would actually need to explicit provide it.

> > > > This is surely my fault as I don't know the measure theory part of the library, but can you clarify the role of `Œº`?
> > > 
> > > 
> > > I am not sure what you mean. The covolume is defined as the volume of any fundamental domain so it is necessary to provide a measure since the hypothesis we have on the ambient space `E` does not ensure that there is a canonical measure on it. It is true that, in most practical cases, `E` will be a `MeasureSpace` so we just want to use the volume of `E`. The tactic `volume_tac` does that automatically is `Œº` is not provided.
> > 
> > 
> > So in practice if I have a lattice in, say, `‚ÑÇ` and I want to use the standard Lebesgue measure I have to write it explicitly?
> 
> Well, we could write `covolume L volume` (in fact, `MeasureTheory.MeasureSpace.volume`) or just `covolume L` (as it is written in `covolume_eq_det`) since Lean can infer automatically what the measure is since it is a `MeasureSpace`. It is only if you want to use an "unusual" measure (or the space `E` has no "canonical" measure) that would actually need to explicit provide it.

If `covolume L` works I am totally happy with it.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8719520599/job/23919031450)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8719520599/job/23919031699)
This is surely my fault as I don't know the measure theory part of the library, but can you clarify the role of `Œº`?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Define the covolume of a `ZLattice`
